metadata.title: Applications of carbon nanomaterials in the plant system: A perspective view on the pros and cons

sections.text:

Review
Applications of carbon nanomaterials in the plant system: A perspective view on the pros and cons
Sandeep Kumar Verma a,b,⁎, Ashok Kumar Das c, Saikat Gantait d, Vinay Kumar e, Ekrem Gurel b a Institute of Biological Science, SAGE University, Baypass Road, Kailod Kartal, Indore 452020, Madhya Pradesh, India b Biotechnology Laboratory, Department of Biology, Bolu Abant Izzet Baysal University, 14030 Bolu, Turkey c Department of Industrial Chemistry, College of Applied Sciences, Addis Ababa Science and Technology University, Addis Ababa 16417, Ethiopia d Department of Genetics and Plant Breeding, Faculty of Agriculture, Bidhan Chandra Krishi Viswavidyalaya, Mohanpur, Nadia 741252, West Bengal, India e Department of Biotechnology, Modern College, Savitribai Phule Pune University, Ganeshkhind, Pune 411016, Maharashtra, India
H I G H L I G H T S G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
• Recent updates on the CNMs augmenting/retarding plant growth are discussed. • CNMs enhance nutrients and water uptake in plants. • CNTs improve seed germination in several plant species. • Carbon dots activate the plant photosystem. • MWCNTs facilitate water channels and increase nitrogenase activity.
Abbreviations:CND, carbon nanodots; CNF, carbonnan nanotube; FCD, fluorescent carbon dots; GO, graphene ox walled carbon nanotube; wsCNO, water-soluble carbon n ⁎ Corresponding author at: Institute of Biological Scienc
E-mail address: sandeep.20j@gmail.com (S.K. Verma).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2019.02.409 0048-9697/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 9 January 2019 Received in revised form 25 February 2019 Accepted 26 February 2019 Available online 27 February 2019
Editor: Damia Barcelo
With the remarkable development in the field of nanotechnology, carbon-based nanomaterials (CNMs) have been widely used for numerous applications in different areas of the plant system. The current understanding about the CNMs' accumulation, translocation, plant growth responses, and stressmodulations in the plant system is far from complete. There have been relentless efforts by the researchers worldwide in order to acquire newer insights into the plant-CNMs interactions and the consequences. The present review intends to update the reader with the status of the impacts of the different CNMs on plant growth. Research reports from the plant biotechnologists have documentedmixed effects (which are dependent on CNMs' concentration) of the CNMs' exposure on plants ranging from enhanced crop yield to acute cytotoxicity. The growth and yield pattern vary from species to species and are dependent on the dosage of the CNMs applied. Studies found an increase in vegetative growth and yield of fruit/seed at lower concentration of CNMs, but a decrease in these observables were also noted when higher concentrations of CNMs were used. In general, at lower concentrations, CNMs were found to be effective in enhancing (water uptake,water transport, seed germination, nitrogenase, photosystemand antioxidant activities), activating (water channels proteins) and promoting (nutrition absorption); all these change when concentrations are raised. All these aspects have been reviewed thoroughly in this article, with a focus on the recent updates on the role of the CNMs in augmenting or retarding plant growth. Sections have beendevoted to the Keywords: Carbon-based nanomaterials Growth responses Plant nanotechnology Translocation Bioaccumulation
ofibers; CNH, carbon nanohorns; CNMs, carbon-based nanoparticles; CNP, carbonnanoparticles; DWCNT, double-walled carbon ide; MCN, mesoporous carbon nanoparticles; NCS, nanocarbon sol; SWCNT, single-walled carbon nanotube; MWCNT, multiano-onion. e, SAGE University, Baypass Road, Kailod Kartal, Indore 452020, Madhya Pradesh, India.
various features of the CNMs and their roles in inducing plant growth, phytotoxic responses of the plants and overall crop improvement. Concluding remarks have been added to propose future directions of research on the CNMs-plant interactions and also to sound a warning on the use of CNMs in agriculture.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nanotechnology involves the manipulation of materials at a length scale [1 to 100 nanometres (nm)] for the purpose of creation of functional materials, sensors and devices. At such a scale, carbon-based nanomaterials (CNMs) possess novel physicochemical properties including typical surfacemorphology, small surface area, increased chemical reactivity etc. These properties distinctively vary from their corresponding ones in the bulk and the variations typically result from the differences in agglomeration shape, surface structure, and small size (P. Wang et al., 2016). The special properties of the CNMs are owing to their stable molecular architecture and their uniform dispersive character in the medium in which these are applied.
Various applications in nanopharmacology and nanomedicine have been developed by exploring the CNMs as smart delivery systems and vehicles as drug carriers (Niazi et al., 2015; Mohajeri et al., 2019). CNMs can be conveniently loaded with an appropriate dosage of drugs or other active substances for delivery to specific target sites within the cell. Although the same principles are applicable to the plant systems, nanotechnology applications in plant science and in sustainable crop production (especially, in the agriculture sector) have not attracted much interests among the scientific community. Thus, the effects of CNMs on plant growth and development are rather less investigated and less understood compared to the corresponding studies on animals (Saxena et al., 2014). However, research reports on the effects of the CNMs on various plant species have started appearing recently (see Supporting Information, Table S1). Despite these efforts, the effects of the CNMs on anatomical, physiological, morphological, biochemical and molecular processes and their mechanisms in different plant systems are not yet fully understood and call for detailed investigations in a systematic manner.
Although themajor objective of the use of nanomaterials in plants is to improve the agricultural productivity, certain research studies have raised critical questions regarding the potential adverse effects of the NPs on human health and environment. Initial reports have described
the unique characters of the NMs and enumerated their fruitful uses as pesticides, seed sprout and growth enhancers, carriers of (phytohormones, herbicides, DNA, and fertilizers) to the cells of plant (Verma et al., 2018). Although research in this multidisciplinary area is promising, it remains imperative to understand the impact of NPs' properties on certain plant responses (Lahiani et al., 2016). Systematic scientific researches focusing on the CNMs' uptake and accumulation in different parts of the plants are still in infancy. In view of this, we have compiled the specialized literature with an up-to-date approach on the area of plant nanotechnology; especially uptake, translocation and accumulation of the CNMs in the plant body and their role in affecting the plant growth and plant's response to imparted toxicity (Table 1, Fig. 1; see also Supporting Information, Table S1).
In this review, we have described the various features of the specific CNMs in marked sections and have discussed the CNMs' roles in inducing plant growth, phytotoxic responses of the plants and overall crop improvement. The section on concluding remarks and future prospects propose directions of the research on CNMs-plant interactions. A warning message on the use of the CNMs in agriculture has also been included at the end.

sections.heading: 2. Effects of carbon-based nanomaterials (CNMs) on plants
sections.text:
CNMs are intentionally manufactured materials (size range: diameter 1 to 100 nm and length from a few μm tomm), whichmay be particles, aggregates or agglomerates (Wang et al., 2013). These engineered nanoparticles (ENPs) can bemetal-based or carbon-based. Metal-based ENPs can be grouped asmetal oxides, metals, and quantumdots (Verma et al., 2018), while the CNMs fall into various categories including nanodots, nanotubes, nanohorns, fullerenes, nanoparticles, nanobeads, nanofibers and nanodiamonds (Kumar et al., 2018). The most often produced CNMs for various applications include fullerenes (C60), carboxyfullerenes, fullerols, graphene, graphene oxide (GO), carbon nanoparticles (CNPs), carbon nanodots (CNDs), carbon nanohorns (CNHs), nanocarbon sol (CNS), water-soluble carbon nano-onions
(ws-CNOs), carbon nanofibers (CNFs), fluorescent carbon dots (FCDs), carbon nanotubes (CNTs) etc. The list is ever-growing with contributions from chemists, biologists and material scientists synthesizing newer CNMs and discovering their special properties and applications.
Exposure of the CNMs on plants and their interactions cause several physiological changes on the selected plant species, depending on the CNMs' properties including size, type, shape, charge, chemical composition, reactivity, surface covering and dosage. The efficacy of a particular type of CNMvaries fromplant to plant and the outcome (null, beneficial, adverse) of the CNM-plant interactions is always concentrationdependent.
The action of the CNMs on plants in relation to variations of charge, size, shape, concentration, exposure amount/time, plant responses (null, positive, negative), role in affecting seed germination, seedling growth and development as well as toxic effects have been presented below for the specific CNMs.

sections.heading: 2.1. Impacts of the CNMs on seed germination, seedling growth, plant development and phytotoxicity
sections.text: Recently, several types of CNMs (fullerenes, fullerols, CNPs, and CNTs) have gained importance because of their potential usage in plant growth regulation. Mostly, the research reports have demonstrated beneficial as well as adverse influence on plants, depending on the CNM types, concentration, exposure time, plant species, and growth conditions onwhich these are applied. In this section, these effects have been discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Impacts of fullerenes (C60) and fullerols [C60(OH)n] on plants
sections.text:
C60 is the fullerene molecule made up of sixty carbon atoms. Polyhydroxylated fullerenes [named fullerenols or fullerols, C60(OH)n], are a class of fullerenes that have numerous hydroxyl groups (OH) attached to the C60 molecule. Fullerols possess magnificent properties
including high water solubility and good biocompatibility, which can be easily tuned by changing the number of OH groups in the moiety. Fullerol NPs find wide-spectrum uses in medical and biological researches owing to their different biological activities (J. Li et al., 2018).
In an earlier work, Liu et al. (2010) reported that, C70(C(COOH)2)4–8 [which is a water-soluble (ws) fullerene malonic acid derivative (FMAD)] supplemented to the germination medium of A. thaliana, caused a deformation of root tips and inhibited root elongation. The effect was shown to be concentration dependent (0.005 to 0.2 mg mL−1) [Liu et al., 2010]. This was correlated with an interference of the auxin transportation system in root tips, accompanied with abnormalities in cell cycles at meristematic region of root as well as decline in the intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS). The FMADdid not affect the seed germination rate, which was attributed to the protective effects of the seed coat in A. thaliana. It needs to be noted here that, all functionalized fullerenes are not able to promote growth in plant. For instance, phytotoxicity impact of the carboxyfullerenes (0.01 to 0.144 mg L−1) had been observed in N. tobacum in vitro cell cultures, associated with a co-induction of oxidative stress and cell wall spoiling (Liu et al., 2013). In their investigation on the CNMs uptake, transmission, and translocation in O. sativa plants, Lin et al. (2009) pre-treated the O. sativa seeds with 400 mg L−1 of fullerene (C70)-NOM (Natural Organic Matter). These authors concluded that the mobility of C70 was elicited by the use of NOM. The C70 accumulations mostly existed in the vascular system and almost none in the tissues of the O. sativa plants (Lin et al., 2009).
The large number of research reports focusing on the influence of C60 on aquatic and terrestrial plants, reported no effects or adverse effects of C60 on plant growth (Tao et al., 2015). In Populus deltoides fragment, grown using hydroponic conditions, the addition of fullerene NPs (2 and 15 mg L−1) into the growth medium, uptake of trichloroethylene (an industrial waste solvent) by the plant was increased by 26% and 82%, respectively (Ma and Wang, 2010). A study by De La Torre-Roche et al. (2013) suggested that when terrestrial plants were grown in fullerene-amended-soil (at fullerene concentration of 500–5000 mg per kg soil), used for immobilization of pesticide (weathered chlordane and DDX) residues, a decreased biomass accumulation was reported: 10, 40, and 44% reduction were reported in S. lycopersicum, G. max, and Z. mays, respectively. The inhibition of root growthwas also noticed in C. pepo by the use of fullereneNP (Kelsey andWhite, 2013). In anotherwork byDe La Torre-Roche et al. (2012), carried out in a vermiculite substrate, 40 mg pot−1 of C60 accumulated the total insecticide content in the plant by 30, 45, and 62% in C. pepo, G. max, and S. lycopersicum, respectively. Notwithstanding, fullerenes were detected notably at the root surface and in the root tissue. A concurrent-conjugated uptake of C60 along with the contaminants, was postulated by De La Torre-Roche et al. (2012). The wsC60 induced change in cell-elasticity in N. tabacum cells was observed by Zhang et al. (2013) and it was found to be consistentwith the change in cell-proliferation rate (Zhang et al., 2013). In hydroponically grown Raphanus sativus, fullerene 14C60 uptake and accumulation in the root tissue (40–47%) and translocation of smaller amounts were also detected in the stems (12–16%) and leaves (18–22%) (Avanasi et al., 2014). The Tectona grandis seedlings exhibited a greater response for taking way nitrogen from large nitrogen contained wastewater, when supplied with 25 mg L−1of C60. This concentration also increased nutrient contents and growth in teak plant (Yavari et al., 2018). The positive growth results of polyhydroxy fullerene (PHF) attest to the feasibility of using it as a stimulator of root growth in barley seedlings (Panova et al., 2016). Using low concentrations of PHF facilitated the expansion of cell walls in the growth zones. However, the use of PHF needed to be restricted because of possible harmful effects of PHF due to its excessive accumulation in the root tissues. Apparently, PHFmoderated stress impacts via inducing the antioxidant machinery (Panova et al., 2016). In O. sativa panicles, Liang et al. (2018) had compared the effects of C60 with those of Cd, Cu and Pb NPs. In the roots and stems of O. sativa, the C60 concentration was found to be much higher compared to the metallic NPs. However, the accumulated concentration of metal ions (Cd2+ + Cu2+ + Pb2+) was much higher in the panicles compared to the concentration of C60 (Liang et al., 2018).
Kole et al. (2013) reported that fullerols (particle size 0.943 to 47.2 nm) exerted beneficial effects on the plant growth (up to 54% in biomass yield). Seed dressings using fullerols even enhanced fruit size (up to 20%), fruit number (up to 59%), fruit weight (up to 70%) and final production ofMomordica charantia (up to 128%), and were also allied with a higher amount of inulin (up to 91%), charantin (up to 20%), lycopene (up to 82%), and cucurbitacin-B (up to 74%) in M. charantha fruits. The fullerol exposure (concentration 1–1000 mg L−1) on B. napus alleviated the negative effects of water stress on seed germination, photosynthesis and final growth. In the water-stressed plants, an appropriate concentration of fullerol enhanced the seed germination, photosynthetic parameters, ABA accumulation and above-ground plant biomass as well as the levels of non-enzymatic [reduced malandialdehyde (MDA) and glutathion (GSH)] and enzymatic antioxidants [catalse (CAT), abcorbate-peroxidase (APx), and guaiacolperoxidase (GPx)] reducing oxidative injury. However, the exogenous effects of polyhydroxy fullerene-fullerol with seeds priming or by foliar spray on leaves was effective in enhancing plant growth and also in the improvement of drought tolerance in B. napus L (Xiong et al., 2018).
Specific fullerol nanoparticles (FNPs) [(C60(OH)24] were able to penetrate plant root tissues and leaves, where the FNPs bind with water in distinct cell compartments. This hydroscopic activity suggested that the FNPs could be advantageous in several plants (Borišev et al., 2016). During the incubation in T. aestivum using fullerol NPs at several test concentrations (0–10.0 μg mL−1), the biomass gain of the leaves and stemswere unaffected; at the same time, root elongation got stimulated at concentration 2.5 μg mL−1. The observed root elongation was
significantly greater than the control, when the FNPs concentrationwas raised to 10.0 μg mL−1. Fullerol further promoted the chlorophyll synthesis (in the range of 2.5–10.0 μg mL−1) in T. aestivum throughout the week-long examination period (C. Wang et al., 2016). In addition, fullerol NPs were found to be mainly distributed in T. aestivum roots [85.68–263.86% mass percentage of dose per gram tissue], with low amounts found in stem and leaves (C. Wang et al., 2016). Z. mays seeds soaked and cultured at different concentrations (0, 5, and 50 μgmL−1) of fullerol [C60(OH)22·8H2O] NPs, showed that therewas little or no effect on the germination frequency (76.11 ± 0.56) of the seeds [control seeds showed a germination frequency (76.67 ± 0.96)], at FNP concentration 5 μg mL−1. Lin et al. (2016) also reported that a decreased ROS accumulation and reduced MDA level was observed in Z. mays exposed to FNPs under drought conditions. Fullerol nanoparticles were confirmed to be an excellent candidate having the potential to serve as plant defense stimulation agents in Z. mays (Lin et al., 2016).
These results have demonstrated that the use of FNPs are effective in promoting germination frequency, improving the drought tolerance, enhancing the above ground biomass, increase of the number of fruits, fruit size and the final yield. Appropriate dose of FNPs had increased the ABA accumulation and photosynthetic parameters as well as level of enzymatic and non-enzymatic antioxidants in the studied plants. However, C60 fullerenes had a negative impact on the plant growth despite the fact that low concentrations of fullerenes showed enhanced root growth in several plants. Furthermore, addition of proper amount of fullerenes to the phytoremediation system can increase the efficiency of the plants for nitrogen fixation and removal of trichoroethylene (an organic contaminant). This leads to infer that the fullerenes can serve as a good candidate in a phytoremediation system. There is a need for further study to investigate the fate of fullerenes in different plant systems.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Impacts of graphene on plants
sections.text:
Graphene belongs to the 2D CNPs family, and because of its distinctive characteristics, it has a lot of potential in a broad range of applications, such as nano-electronic devices, energy storage, water-splitting agents (to produce the green fuel, hydrogen), transparent conductors, biomedical and environmental protection (Zhang et al., 2016).
Nair et al. (2012) reported thatO. sativa seedlings germinated onMS medium supplemented with graphene were healthier along with welldeveloped root and shoot systems than the control seedlings. In the similar study, Zhang et al. (2015) had kept tomato seeds cottoncushioned in a glass flask container and then treated with 40 μg mL−1 of powdered graphene. The germination frequency of the seeds was increased by 26.6% (after 2 days), 43.4% (after 4 days), and 13.5% (after 6 days), when compared with the controls (untreated). These authors had established the favorable influence of graphene on seed germination and pointed out to the fact that graphene could perforate and break the seed-husks to assist uptake of water. This ensured an enhanced seed germination and a greater germination percentage. Liu et al. (2015) reported that delaying effects on the O. sativa seed germination frequency were observed when graphene concentration (5–200 mg L−1) was increased. Another study indicated that graphene (250–1500 mg L−1) adversely affected the growth and development of T. aestivum plants. Zhang et al. (2016) opined that the phytotoxicity of graphene on the plants could bring in a combined impact (of the impaired growth of root hairs, inhibition of photosynthesis, imbalance of nutrient homeostasis, and oxidative stress). In Z. mays seedlings, sulfonated graphene NPs stimulated a hormesis impact on plant height, i.e., at low concentration (50mg L−1) stimulation and a high concentration (500mg L−1) inhibition (Ren et al., 2016). Sulfonated grapheneNPs (concentration 50mg/kg)were found to significantly increase the accumulation of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB8 and PCB18) in roots, but decline the same in the stems and leaves of the Z. mays seedlings (Ren et al., 2018).
In summary, exposure to graphene of the selected plants had resulted concentration-dependent effects. While germination frequency certainly gets enhanced due to the graphene's capability of transporting water, adverse effects were also observed at higher concentrations. Duration of graphene exposure has a role in inducing phytotoxicity in the studied plants.

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Impacts of graphene oxide (GO; C140H42O20) on plants
sections.text:
GO is a vitalmember of the graphene family. It has the special potential to be used in industry and as a biomedicine, because of its distinctive characteristics and 2D structure (Georgakilas et al., 2015).
In plants, use of water-soluble graphene oxide (wsGO, made soluble with sodium ions as the counterions) nanoparticles showed enhanced release of ROS (identified to be a major cause of growth retardation) in the seedling stages of cabbage, tomato, red spinach and lettuce (Begum et al., 2011). Necrotic lesions and cell death occurred by the application of GO which was attributed to the development of oxidative stress by the enhanced ROS release (Begum et al., 2011). These authors found that graphene (at highest concentration 2000 mg L−1) inhibited the plant growth (up to 78%), as confirmed by the decrease in leaf number (up to 53%), leaf area (up to 91%), root weight (up to 86%), shoot weight (up to 92%) and plant aboveground biomass (up to 61%) and underground biomass (up to 78%). All of these adverse effects were found to be dose-dependent (500–2000 mg L−1 GO) (Begum et al., 2011). Using GO (100–1600 mg L−1) as an additive in the nutrient solution, the absorption of GO (particle size 0.5–5.0 μm) by the roots of V. faba L. seedlings had resulted a positive effect (GO concentration 400 mg L−1). This was supplemented by a significant improvement of the plant health, indicated by decreased levels of H2O2 and lipid and protein oxidation (Anjum et al., 2014). A significant decrease in the plant growth parameters in V. faba L. was observed at GO concentration 1600 mg L−1 accompanied with an induced oxidative stress and the increase of the electrolyte leakage, detrimental to the seedling growth (Anjum et al., 2014). The same researchers, Anjum et al. (2013) had assessed the influence of GO on the V. faba L. and detected a glutathione redox system, which is a key factor of the cellular redox homeostasis. A dose-dependent (order: 1600 N 200 N 100 mg L−1 GO) stress-response was observed in V. faba L., accompanied with a decreased oxidative enzyme activity (Anjum et al., 2013). These authors showed that low (100 and 200 mg L−1 GO) and high (1600 mg L−1 GO) concentrations of GO applications impaired the antioxidative glutathione metabolism. Interestingly, moderate GO concentrations (400 and 800 mg L−1) increased the glutathione pool in V. faba L. (Anjum et al., 2013). It was found that GO was more distributed in Arabidopsis seedlings under stress conditions and the GO NPs were translocated into roots, stem, and leaves (Wang et al., 2014). The authors hypothesized that, under stress conditions, GO NPsmight inducemembrane ion leakage and oxidative stress, which in turn induced GO translocation from the roots to the leaves (Wang et al., 2014). In a co-exposure study with GO and arsenate [As (V)], Hu et al. (2014) established that exposure toGO (0.1–10mg L−1) increased the antagonistic impact of arsenate in seeds ofwheat, remarkably reducing the shoot length, chlorophyll level and fresh mass, of the exposed plants. Furthermore, the activity of superoxide dismutase (SOD) and peroxidase (POD), were augmented in a concentration-dependent approach. In another study, using hydrated graphene ribbon (HGR) in the sprout of old T. aestivum L. seeds, Hu and Zhou (2014) reported that, compared to graphene and GO, the HGRs enhanced seed germination by 15%, increased root differentiation by about 52% to 59%, and also increased resistance to oxidative stress. Through metabolomics analysis, it was revealed that the HGRs up-regulated cell membrane integrity, amino acid, carbohydrate, and nitrogen sequestration, fatty acids metabolism, oxidation resistance, and permeability (Hu and Zhou, 2014). Plants could exhibit a resilient anti-GO transport activity from root tip to shoot apex, which was evident from GO NPs' translocation pattern in Arabidopsis (Zhao et al., 2015). In contrast, when wild-type S. lycopersicum plants and the corresponding transgenic plants
were exposed with GO (20 mg L−1), shorter seminal root length was observed in the transgenic plants than control (Jiao et al., 2016). This was attributed to the quick accumulation of the plant hormone, abscisic acid (ABA) in the transgenic plants (Jiao et al., 2016). GO NPs had a substantial influence on B. napus ‘Zhongshuang 11’. The 50mg L−1 GO exposure controlled the growth of B. napus root and altered biosynthesis and level of ABA and indole-3-acetic-acid (IAA) (Cheng et al., 2016). O. sativa seedlings were exposed to 0.01–1mg L−1 of GO nanosheets for a week under hydroponic conditions, followed by a week of post exposure (without GO). The studies had confirmed significant up-regulation of phenylalanine metabolism and secondary metabolism in GO-exposed O. sativa roots (Zhou and Hu, 2017). In their study on T. aestivum, Chen et al. (2017) had applied steady isotope labeling to determine graphene content in plant systems and revealed that 13C-GO gathered in roots of wheat at lower levels. The authors observed that large size of 13C-GO NPs hinders the nanoparticles' translocation to stem and leaves. Any direct contract and bioaccumulation of GO in the root repressed growth of the root system, changed the cellular ultrastructure and root structure, and steered to hindrance of the growth and development of seedling (Chen et al., 2017). GO induced the inhibition of photosynthesis, seedling length, and biomass gain of naked oats in hydroponic culture. The toxicological mechanism in A. sativa L. was attributed to the oxidative damage (Chen et al., 2018). GO with a concentration of 5 mg L−1, efficiently decreased the damage from Cu stress in the duckweed (Hu et al., 2018). It was established that a low concentration of GO remarkably stimulated the germination of chive and spinach in soil. In order to speed up the germination of the spinach seeds, the oxygen-containing functional groups of GO gathered water, and the hydrophobic carbon atoms (the sp2 domains) transported the water to the seeds (Hu et al., 2018). A recent study on maize (Zea mays) seedlings indicated that GO NPs (100–1500 mg L−1) could change the effects of Cd2+ on seed germination, seedling growth, and uptake of Cd2+ in solution through the adsorption of the Cd2+ ions on the GO surface (Yin et al., 2018). These authors found that, using a solution with cadmium concentration 20 mg L−1, the Cd2+ accumulation in roots were increased by the presence of GO (100 to 500 mg L−1), while no evident effects were observed in low Cd2+ solution (5 mg L−1). Shoot Cd2+ concentrations were reduced by using low GO concentration (100 mg L−1) and were increased by high GO concentration (N500mg L−1) in solution culture (Yin et al., 2018). A recent research report demonstrated that exposure to high doses of GO in vitro impairs the pollen performances of two species (Corylus avellana L. and N. tabacum L.) due to acidic character of GO (Carniel et al., 2018). These authors further reported that pollen germination and tube elongation were affected at GO concentration N50 μg mL−1, decreased from 68% to 58% in Corylus avellana L. and from 20% to 19% in N. tabacum L. (Carniel et al., 2018). In Malus domestica, results indicated that the application of GO (0.1 mg L−1) had a beneficial influence on root formation [increased the transcript abundance of auxin-efflux-carrier genes (PIN7, ABCB1) and auxin-influx-carrier genes (LAX2, LAX3)], while adversely impacted the root growth (F. Li et al., 2018). The number of lateral roots and root lengths of adventitious roots significantly decreased as a response to exposure to the tested concentrations of GO (0.1, 1 and 10mg L−1). These results also indicated that the 0.1 mg L−1 GO treatment increased adventitious root formation; however, adventitious root was inhibited by the 10 mg L−1 GO treatment. Exposure to GO enhanced the transcript level and oxidative stress enzymes (SOD, CAT, and POD) activities (F. Li et al., 2018). The recent findings by S. Shen et al. (2018) on rice (Oryza sativa) indicated that GO nanosheets (of thickness 1–2 nm) had remarkable positive impacts on plant growth, development, abscisic acid (ABA), MDA and indole-3-acetic acid (IAA) contents and enzymatic activities [SOD, CAT and POD]. All these effects were found to be concentration dependent (5–50 mg L−1 of GO)
and also specific to the plant variety (S. Shen et al., 2018). Highconcentrations of GO (50 mg L−1) were harmful to rice and inhibited root growth. The average number of lateral roots increased from 7.1 to 9.3 when GO concentration was increased from 0 to 25 mg L−1 in Shenyou9521 (rice variety name) and decreased from 9.05 to 5.95, when Jingchuxiang (rice variety name) was treated with 50 mg L−1 GO (S. Shen et al., 2018). The presence of the graphene and GO nanosheets inhibited the total depuration of three-ringed phenanthrene (PAHs) from the actively growing spinach leaf surfaces. The influence of GO nanosheets on the impending hazard linkedwith PAHs infection in consumable vegetables is a subject of concern and call for immediate action by the agricultural scientists (Lin et al., 2017; Sun et al., 2018).
Onemay infer that, at reduced doses, the GO NPs exert a positive effect on seed germination, seedling growth, and root growth in several plant species (for example, using 0.01–1.0mg L−1 GO in O. sativa plants or, using 5–50 mg L−1 GO in duckweed plants). Application of larger doses (N50 mg L−1) of GO usually result with adverse effects in most of the plants. With respect to mechanism, GO nanosheets (of thickness 1–2 nm) were proved to bring in more beneficial effects on plant growth and development.

sections.heading: 2.1.4. Impacts of mesoporous carbon nanoparticles (MCNs) on plants
sections.text:
Due to their stable mesoporous structure, high surface area, and excellent catalytic performance, MCNs derived frommetal-organic frameworks have a broad range of applications, including energy storage, catalysis, photodynamic therapy and drug delivery (S. Wang et al., 2016).
Recent results indicate that exposure of MCNs (50 and 150 mg L−1) to O. sativa brought in adverse effects through alteration of the levels of important plant hormones (Hao et al., 2018). The induced toxicity due toMCNs' exposurewas found to depend on the particle size. Thesefindings represent the potential risk of MCNs on agricultural and horticultural crops, underscoring the concern about the human and cattle health hazards that might arise owing to usage of NMs and NMintegrated produces in horticulture and agriculture (Hao et al., 2018).

sections.heading: 2.1.5. Impacts of carbon nanoparticles (CNPs) on plants
sections.text:
Carbon nanoparticles (CNPs) possess extraordinary electrical conductivity, heat conductivity and excellent mechanical properties. The CNPs are composed of pure carbon, therefore, exhibit high stability, low toxicity, environmental friendliness, and good conductivity (Yan et al., 2016). CNPs are found inmany applications in the biomedical sector such as drug delivery, gene transfer and bio-imaging (Lin et al., 2016).
According to Liang et al. (2013), application of CNPs (varying concentrations 0–125mg/pot) onN. tabacum L. plants resulted in enhanced growth at different stages as compared with the plant growth obtained by using conventional fertilizers. These authors also reported that the application of CNPs (size not specified) increased the contents of nitrogen and potassium inN. tabacum plant organs. The potassiumcontent of N. tabacum leaves increased by 21.05, 23.26, and 36.84% at the maturity stage, which was beneficial to the quality improvement of N. tabacum. Saxena et al. (2014) had investigated the dose dependent influence of ws-CNPs (size range from 20 to 50 nm) on Triticum aestivum. The wsCNPs (containing an average of 20% of carboxylic groups attached) were isolated from naturally occurring raw CNPs present in biochar. Wheat (Triticum aestivum) plants were treated with ws-CNPs (10–150 mg L−1) in the soil for up to 20 days and the results indicated that an optimum growth of wheat plants occurred at 50 mg L−1 treatment, with shoot and root lengths enhanced up to three folds compared to the controls (Saxena et al., 2014). Kumar et al. (2018) had investigated the effects of CNPs on photomorphogenesis and flowering time in Arabidopsis thaliana. The CNPs (concentration 0–500 μg mL−1) were uptaken by the plant, accumulated in leaf tissues and induced earlier flowering by altering both phytochrome B (PHYB) and photoperiod-
dependent pathways. The CNPs (size not specified) promoted hypocotyl length under far-red, red, and blue light because of the hyposensitive impact of all the three major photoreceptor signaling pathways (Kumar et al., 2018). Exploring the importance of CNPs in crop plants under in vitro or ex vitro environments could unfold an innovative non-transgenic strategy for improvement of economically important crops (Kumar et al., 2018).
The application of the CNPs increased plant growth and promoted micro-macro-elements absorption and accumulation quantity, thereby increasing fertilizer efficiency and improving plant quality. The wsCNPs could be a preferable choice than manure or fertilizer alone, because of slow and controlled release of nutrients for better assimilation through the plants.

sections.heading: 2.1.6. Impacts of carbon nanodots (CNDs) and fluorescent carbon dots (FCDs) on plants
sections.text:
As a unique fluorescent carbonic nanomaterial, carbon dots (CDs) are usually minute CNPs with regular surface passivation through several functionalities. They have multiple exclusive features; for example, favorable water-solubility, facile modification, chemical inertness, outstanding biocompatibility and little cytotoxicity. Based on all such benefits, CDs exhibit multipurpose functions in chemical sensing, photocatalysis, photodynamic therapy, and especially in biological applications (Chen et al., 2016). CDs have been widely used in bioimaging and other biosensor applications; however the effects of the CDs on plants have rarely been investigated.
Tripathi and Sarkar (2015) noted an increased root growth (ten times as that of the control) of wheat (Triticum aestivum) through ten days exposure to 150 mg L−1 ws-carbon nanodots (ws-CNDs). In another work on Z. mays, Chen et al. (2016) had investigated that after treatment in the sand matrix mixed with ws-CNDs (0–2000 mg L−1) for one month, the plant toxicity of ws-CNDs was proved to be concentration-dependent. ws-CNDs at concentration 250 or 500 mg L−1 resulted no toxicity in Z. mays. Notwithstanding, at 1000 or 2000 mg L−1, the ws-CNDs significantly reduced the shoot fresh weight (by 38% and 72%, respectively), and root fresh weight (by 57% and 68%, respectively). In addition, in Z. mays roots, the exposure of ws-CNDs at 2000 mg L−1 remarkably enhanced the H2O2 content (6.5 times higher than that of the control) and lipid peroxidation (1.65 times higher) (Chen et al., 2016). The antioxidant enzymes activities also showed an enhancement due to thews-CND treatment: CAT higher by 2 times, ascorbate peroxidase (APOX) increased by 1.5 times, guaiacol peroxidase (GPOX) increased by 1.9 times and SOD increased by 1.9 times. Moreover, ws-CNDs were noticed in leaves (mesophyll cells) and in roots (detached vascular bundle, cortex, and root-cap cells) via fluorescence microscopy analysis, indicating that ws-CNDs were absorbed by root, translocated through stem and reached leaves in a systemic manner in Z. mays (Chen et al., 2016). N. tabacum leaves were directly injected with water-soluble fluorescent nanodots (wsFCDs) by Sai et al. (2018). As a consequence, photosynthetic rate of N. tabacum leaves was enhanced by 18%, aiding the UV-to-blue light conversion by the FCDs (Sai et al., 2018).
In V. radiata plants, incubation with different concentrations (0.1 to 1.0 mg mL−1) of CDs stimulated positive physiological responses and imposed no phytotoxicity on plant growth, as reported by Li et al. (2016). The lengths of the stem and root exhibited an increasing trend, up to 0.4 mg mL−1 of the CDs. Confocal microscopic results indicated that the fluorescent CDswere carried by the vascular system from the roots to the stems and finally to the leaves, via apoplastic pathway (Li et al., 2016). The authors carried out an ‘uptake kinetics’ study on the plants, which exhibited that throughout germination and growth phases of V. radiata, the CDswere profusely raised. Moreover, in vivo visualization of the fluorescent CDs provided feasible for their prospective applications as cargos or delivery vehicles in plants, based on their novel optical properties (Li et al., 2016). A simple and unique approach to economical synthesis of high quality ws-FCDs (average size ~ 2.5 nm) had
been through hydrothermal treatment of the pseudo-stem of banana plants (Vandarkuzhali et al., 2017). The resultant ws-FCDs did not show any surface passivation towards oxidizing agents. Studies demonstrated that the CDs can be used as fluorescent probe for cellular imaging of Fe3+ (Vandarkuzhali et al., 2017). Zheng et al. (2017) had experimented on hydroponically grown Rome lettuce (Lactuca sativa) using several concentrations of CDs,whichwere synthesized from rapeseed pollen. The results suggested that the CDs (20–30 mg L−1) could enhance the lettuce production yield significantly with a decrease in the nitrate content. These authors confirmed that the CDs were transported from nutrient solutions to vessels within the xylem of vascular bundles, both by apoplast and cellular pathways, along with the transpiration stream. This study indicated that CDs synthesized from rapeseed pollen can act as a perfectmaterial for labeling cells in vivo, affecting plant physiology processes and increasing plant yields (Zheng et al., 2017). When V. radiata sprouts were grown with various concentrations (0.02–0.12 mgmL−1) of CDs, a concentration dependent-effect on the growth of sprouts was observed (Wang et al., 2018). Root elongation, stem elongation, increased biomass and carbohydrates content (increase up to 21.9%)were found in theCDs-exposed V. radiata sprouts. Further analysis confirmed that the CDs can enhance the photosystem activity (Rubisco activity and chlorophyll content) by upgrading the electron transfer rate (Wang et al., 2018). Fluorescent images obtained by Qian et al. (2018) showed that all three [bared CDs, CD-PEI (modified by Polyethylenimine), and CD-PAA (modified by Polyacrylic acid)] types of CDs, exposed to the C. maxima seedlings could accumulate in the roots and in the shoots tissues, even though their distribution pattern was different for each CDs. All the three types of CDs potentially trigger the antioxidant defense systems; however, such alteration was higher in the roots as compared to the shoots (Qian et al., 2018).
These studies showed that ws-CNDs easily cross the biological barriers in young plant saplings to carry forwardmore water and nutrients to increase the growth and development of plants. These findings have paved themode for the possible uses of CNDs in plant cell and tissue imaging. Nevertheless, as themolecularmechanismof the induced toxicity of the CNDs have not yet been investigated, their probable influences on other plant growth, food safety and the environment still require advanced explorations.

sections.heading: 2.1.7. Impacts of carbon nanohorns (CNHs) on plants
sections.text:
Singlewall carbon nanohorns (SWCNHs) are single graphitic tubules with length of 40–50 nm and diameter of 2–5 nm. The interstitial channels and cylindrical inner nanospace are among the features that distinguish nanohorns from other CNMs. In fact, the inner nanospace in the nanohorns is large enough to store a large amount ofmolecules of interest (Lahiani et al., 2015).
CNHs have also been reported to exhibit positive impacts on the growth of terrestrial plants (Lahiani et al., 2015). In their studies, these authors had exposed N. tabacum cells to 25 and 100 μg mL−1 of CNHs concentrations for 24 h. No significant effects were observed in N. tabacum cells exposed to CNHs at 25 μg mL−1, while 78% increase in growth of cultured cells was observed at concentration 100 μg mL−1 compared to the controls (Lahiani et al., 2015).
The presence of inner namespace in CNHs has unique properties, whichmakes them interesting candidate for use as cargoes or smart delivery systems for various applications in the field of plant biotechnology. For example, CNHs can be used for delivery of proteins, DNA, herbicides and other chemicals. The use of CNHs in agriculture and horticulture has showed mixed effects, dependent on the dose and exposure duration.

sections.heading: 2.1.8. Impacts of nanocarbon sol (NCS) on plants
sections.text:
The nanocarbon sol (NCS) of proper concentration had promoted the growth and development of N. tabacum plant (Baolin et al., 2013). When the nanosol concentration was 10 mg L−1, the biomass of N. tabacum shoot was significantly higher as compared to the control
group. Nano-carbon sol also promoted thenitrogen (N2), potassium(K), calcium (Ca) and magnesium (Mg) absorption and increased their contents in N. tabacum shoots (Baolin et al., 2013). Jian et al. (2014) had found out the impact of NCS application on the physiological characteristics of the root system, K absorption, and related gene expression level of flue-cured tobacco varieties. The outcomes showed that, at concentration ranges of 5–10mg L−1 and 10–20mg L−1, NCS significantly promoted the growth of rhizome, promoted the root and shoot biomass accompanied with an upgraded K absorption and accumulation in the leaves of tobacco varieties (Jian et al., 2014). While NCS concentrations were increased, absorbing area, soluble protein content, vigor of the root system of tobacco varieties exhibited an initial increase, which subsequently got reduced (Jian et al., 2014). In suspension culture experiments on tobacco cell growth by Zhenjie et al. (2017), NCS presented a good biocompatibility at the early and middle culture stages without significantly affecting the density, packed cell volume and mortality of the suspension cells. At the late culture stage, nanocarbon sol had an inhibitory effect at a concentration of 10mg L−1, which decreased the cell density and cell viability. This was likely to be associated with the aging of cultured cells (Zhenjie et al., 2017).
Although the number of studies on NCS's exposure to plants is not plenty, the published research reports indicated that low-dose NCS promoted plant growth, development and nutrient absorption in plants. For example, in tobacco, NCS concentration ranges 5–10 mg L−1 and 10–20 mg L−1 were beneficial for promoting rhizome growth, root growth and shoot biomass. Like the other CNMs, the use of NCS at higher concentrations resulted with adverse effects.

sections.heading: 2.1.9. Impacts of water-soluble carbon nano-onions (wsCNOs) on plants
sections.text:
Carbon nano-onions (CNOs) are a member of the fullerene family, and they are made up of polyhedral shaped and quasi-spherical graphitic layers close to one another. The distance between the graphitic layers in CNOs is 0.335 nm. The key areas of CNOs applications are in medical, pharmaceutical and electrochemical capacitors applications (Mykhailiv et al., 2017).
Water soluble CNOs (wsCNOs) were extracted from the pyrolysis of woodwaste by Sonkar et al. (2012). Various concentrations (10, 20, and 30 μg mL−1) of wsCNOs were used for hydroponic germination studies on C. arietinum seeds. Exposure-dependent growth enhancement in C. arietinum plants was noticed under 5 and 10 days treatments than untreated controls (Sonkar et al., 2012). The enhancement of plant growth was demonstrated by electron microscopy to confirm that these wsCNOs were absorbed by plants and became fixed in the xylem vessels. Such effects enhanced the biomass and fruit yield (Sonkar et al., 2012). First generation C. arietinum seeds harvested from wsCNOs (bio-waste derived) exposed plants showed a considerable increase in their yield and enhanced protein, overall dimensions, metallic micronutrient (Mn, Mo, Cu, Zn, Fe, and Ni) content and stored electrolytes (Tripathi et al., 2017). These results showed that wsCNOs enhanced plant growth, increased fruit yield, enhanced protein content, and increasedmicronutrient absorption. Further, thewsCNOs are safe to the plant cells and can act as efficient plant growth stimulants (nanofertilizers).
2.1.10. Impacts of carbon nanofibers (CNFs) on plants In a recent study, activated carbon fibers (ACFs) were used as an adsorbent and support for transition metals (Ag, Cu, Fe, Ni, and Zn), in order to explore several environmental and biological applications (Ashfaq et al., 2013). These authors grew CNFs on substrate-ACFs by chemical vapor decomposition (CVD) method, where Cu/Ag NPs acted as the catalyst. The cytotoxicity of the developed ACFs/CNFs was shown to be comparable to, or less than that of the commercially used adsorbents (including silica, alumina, zeolite, granular activated carbon and CNTs). The cytotoxic evaluation study by the authors (Ashfaq et al., 2013) paved theway for the application of ACFs/CNFs in environmental and biological systems. Hence, an aqueous colloidal dispersion of copper
nanoparticle-grown carbon nanofiber (Cu-CNF) was examined for its use as a stimulant for crop yields in C. arietinum seeds (Ashfaq et al., 2017). The results clearly showed that the Cu-CNFs boosted the water uptake capacity via the root system, increased germination rate, enhanced lengths of root and shoot, and increased protein and chlorophyll contents of the C. arietinum plants (Ashfaq et al., 2017).
These reports suggest that Cu-CNFs are ideal engineered nanomaterials (ENMs) which can act as the carrier for micronutrients and stimulants for plant growth. The mechanistic aspects of the micronutrient delivery system using the CNFs need to be explored further.

sections.heading: 2.1.11. Impacts of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) on plants
sections.text:
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are a member of the carbon family. Their crystal structures are very close to graphite, comprising of sp2 bonded carbon atoms (compare: in diamond, the carbon atoms are sp3 hybridized). The structure of the CNTs has direct influence on its properties including thermal and electrical conductivities, density, and lattice structure. Different CNTs (SWCNTs, DWCNTs, and MWCNTs) have different properties and application potentials (Georgakilas et al., 2015).
Brassica juncea (Indian mustard, Chinese mustard) and Phaseolus mungo seeds were found to germinate normally in 10, 20 and 40 mg L−1 MWCNT, which indicated the non-hazardous nature of the CNTs (Ghodake et al., 2010). Water-soluble CNTs were shown to promote the growth of C. arietinum plants by enhancing their capacity to absorb and reserve water (Tripathi et al., 2011). MWCNTs showed beneficial effects at 40 μg mL−1 on the Lycopersicum esculantum (var. Arka Vikas) seeds' germination and plant growthwhen compared to the control group (Morla et al., 2011). Furthermore, the germination of L. esculantum seeds in MS medium (containing functionalized COOHMWCNT) and the plants grown in it were found to assimilate the MWCNTs and bio-distribute them into roots, leaves, and fruits (Khodakovskaya et al., 2011). A stimulative effect, prevalently of the MWCNTs, on seed germination and/or seedling root elongation, was also observed in T. aestivum (Wang et al., 2012). The formation of water channel protein [aquaporin (LeAqp1)] was triggered in tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) plants by the MWCNTs activated with multiple groups [such as COOH− and polyethylene glycol (PEG)] in comparison to untreated plants or plants subjected to weakly distributed and strongly grouped MWCNTs (Villagarcia et al., 2012). It is well known that water helps to channel proteins for plant development and is directly involved in the process of seed germination and root water uptake (Maurel, 2007). Khodakovskaya et al. (2013) demonstrated that expression of water channel protein (LeAqp2 gene) can be significantly activated in tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) roots by exposure to CNTs as compared to control group (without CNTs). In another communication, these authors' (Khodakovskaya et al., 2012) investigations revealed an upregulation of several genes related to the effect of MWCNTs (5 to 500 mg mL−1) exposure on N. tabacum cells, including an aquaporin (NtPIP1) involved in water transport and two genes (NtLRX and CycB) involved in cell division and cell wall formation (Khodakovskaya et al., 2012). Generation of ROS assessed by dichlorodihydro-fluorescein diacetate assay (DCFH-DA), hydrogen peroxide detectionwith 3–3′ diaminobenzidine (DAB) staining, and nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) staining confirmed the presence of ROS generated in the leaves of red spinach (Amaranthus tricolor L.) grown with MWCNTs (Begum et al., 2011). In their report on paddy (Oryza sativa), Jiang et al. (2013) found that CNTs applied at 0 to 100 μg mL−1, increased stem and root length of the paddy seedlings. The overall stimulation in growth in the presence of CNTs was attributed to the increase in nutrient uptake through an improved water delivery by the MWCNTs. When the concentrationwas increased to 150 μgmL−1, the root activity, root length and stem length were reduced in comparison with the concentration of 100 μg mL−1. The results demonstrated that the CNTs could promoteO. sativa seed germination and root growth at lower concentrations but might have phytotoxic effects at high concentrations. A previous study by Larue et al. (2012) dwelt on the uptake of 14C-
MWCNT in Brasica napus and in T. aestivum. Miralles et al. (2012) had studied T. aestivum and Medicago sativa to investigate the effects of MWCNTs (industrial grade) and their impurities on seed germination. The nanomaterial was activated with the aid of Fe3O4 NPs. Adsorption of the CNTs on root surfaces was detected that resulted in a substantial elongation of root in alfalfa andwheat, neverthelesswith limited uptake and movement of MWCNTs (Miralles et al., 2012). In contrast, an enhancement of plant growth in tomato by using CNTs was reported by Khodakovskaya et al. (2009). Using analytical methods, it was established that the CNTs (10–40 μg mL−1) were able to penetrate the thick seed coat and support water uptake inside the seeds. As a consequence, seed germination and growth of the L. esculantum seedlings were affected (Khodakovskaya et al., 2009). The same group of authors had reported that theMWCNTs increase plant growth by not only altering water balance but also by positively affecting gene expression in L. esculantum and N. tabacum (Khodakovskaya et al., 2011, 2012, 2013). It was demonstrated that low doses of different types of CNTs penetrate seed coats and activate seed germination and plant growth (Lahiani et al., 2013). Using the PCR analysis, immuno-staining, and electronmicroscopy, Yan et al. (2013) confirmed that the penetration and accumulation of SWCNTs into Z. mays roots might change the expression of genes controlling the seminal root and the growth of root hairs. The SWCNTs were found to benefit the seminal root but had adverse effects on the root hairs. In tomato seedlings, the presence of MWCNTs in the nutrient medium showed a higher percentage of Ca and K in the plants than the respective control (Tiwari et al., 2013b). Serag et al. (2013) had studied the effect of CNTs at the molecular level. These authors had shown that the length and diameter of SWCNTs are the limiting factors for their penetration into the cell walls of the plants. Smaller size of CNMs may diffuse and leak but if it is too large it may remain out of the cell and immobilized, even if it has been able to penetrate the plant cell wall. Haghighi and da Silva (2014) had examined the effect of CNTs on vegetables including L. esculentum (tomato), Allium cepa L. (onion), R. sativus L. (crocus) and Brassica rapa L. (mustard). The CNTs at concentrations 10–40 mg L−1 had improved the L. esculentum (tomato) and Allium cepa L. (onion) germination more than in B. rapa L. (mustard) and R. sativus L. (crocus). The maximum germination percentage in Allium cepa L. and L. esculentumwere 95 and 8%, respectively. But in R. sativus L., the control showed the maximum germination percent (96%) under laboratory conditions. The CNTs did not alter the germination and growth in B. rapa L. At 40 mg L−1, the CNTs had caused harmful and toxic effects on R. sativus L. and Allium cepa L. seed germination (Haghighi and da Silva, 2014). Tiwari et al. (2013a) highlighted that use of MWCNTs had increased mineral nutrient (Ca and Fe) supply to the Z. mays seedlings by the action of themutually opposing forces of inflow of water and its withholding in the medium by the transientdipole interactions between ion-CNT. Ghosh et al. (2011, 2015a, 2015b) attempted to find a correlation between MWCNT uptake and DNA damage in A. cepa plant cells. Recent studies on Phoenix dactylifera L. date palm by Taha et al. (2016) pointed out that MWCNTs can pierce through plant tissues and enter its cells. It was noted that CNTs can facilitate the adsorption of nutrients and their transportation into the plant tissues. Nevertheless, the sodium-containing nutrients might be prevented by the CNTs from entering into the plant cells (Taha et al., 2016).
Results demonstrated that treatment byMWCNTs at low concentrations could stimulate tolerance in seedlings against drought conditions (from low tomoderate levels) via enhancement ofwater uptake and activation of the plant defense system in Cucurbita pepo L. (Hatami, 2017). In bread wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), MWCNTs had resulted in augmental enhancement in xylem-phloem size, epidermal cells, stomatal density, grain number, biomass, andwater uptake (Joshi et al., 2018). MWCNTs could enhance the number of nodules and increase the function of nitrogenase in the rhizobium-plant communication (Yuan et al., 2017). Moreover, gene expression analysis exhibited that the rise of nodulation using MWCNTs was associated with up-regulation of a few
genes involved in the signaling pathway. Particularly, the expression ofNIN, a crucial gene controlling the nodules formation,was remarkably improved to two-folds using the MWCNTs at the initial nodulation phase (Yuan et al., 2017). It was found that MWCNT could enhance fruit production in hydroponically exposed L. esculentum (tomato) plants (McGehee et al., 2017). It was also reported that absorption of MWCNT through tomato fruits had notably affected the total metabolome content of the fruit, as confirmed by the high performance liquid chromatography-gas chromatography (HPLC-MS) (McGehee et al., 2017). It was clearly established that the effects of MWCNTs on growth parameters and heavy metal accumulation in plant seedlings were strongly dependent on the heavy metal type, concentration of the MWCNTs and the plant species (Oloumi et al., 2018).
Investigations on the effects of MWCNTs onO. sativa suspension cultures revealed an increase in the ROS formation, associated with reduced cell viability (Tan et al., 2009). The capability of SWCNTs to penetrate the cell wall and cell membrane of intact plant cells was examined by Liu et al. (2009). Using confocal fluorescence images, these authors found evidences of the cellular uptake of both SWCNT/DNA conjugates and SWCNT/fluorescein isothiocyanate. These studies demonstrated that SWCNTs hold great promise as nano-transporters for walled plant cells. Furthermore, the SWCNTs could deliver different cargos into different plant cell organelles (Liu et al., 2009). Phenotypes of plant seemed to be affected byMWCNTs, whereinMWCNTs were reported to hinder the usual plant growth of G. max (Zhai et al., 2015). SWCNTs are known to produce phytotoxicity in Arabidopsis and O. sativa leading to the death of ~25% of protoplast (cell without cell wall) in 6 h (Shen et al., 2010). Other researchers reported that the MWCNT-exposed red spinach (Amaranthus tricolor L.) plants revealed growth inhibition and cell death following two weeks of hydroponic culture (Begum and Fugetsu, 2012). The MWCNTs had caused negative effects on leaf and root morphology of the red spinach. Biomarkers of the NPs toxicity, ROS and cell damage in the red spinach were significantly enhanced during the two weeks post-exposure. These deleterious effects were successfully reversed when MWCNTs were supplemented with vitamin C (C6H8O6), suggesting a role of the ROS in theMWCNT-induced toxicity. The authors inferred that the plausible mechanism of the MWCNT-induced toxicity was the plant's oxidative stress (Begum and Fugetsu, 2012). The inductions of membrane damage and cell death in Amaranthus dubiuswere attributed to the penetration of the MWCNTs into the plant cells (Begum et al., 2012). These authors also found that after 15 days of hydroponic culture, L. sativa root length and shoot lengthwere greatly decreased following exposure at 1000–2000 mg L−1 of MWCNT. Voleti and Wait (2014) had pointed out that photosynthesis, transpiration, and stomatal conductance in A. thaliana grown in the presence of CNTs (concentration 25 μg mL−1) was notably reduced compared to the control treatment. Carbon gain was reduced by 15% in plants grown in the presence of CNTs (Voleti and Wait, 2014). In contrast, carbon dioxide (CO2) compensation point was appreciably higher in the CNT-grown plants as compared to the control plants. Plant dry weight (DW) was not significantly affected either in CNT-grown plant or in control (Voleti andWait, 2014). An appreciable reduction (11%) in chlorophyll fluorescence was observed in the CNT-grown plants, compared with the controls. The CNTs were found to be toxic to the A. thaliana plants at the whole plant level (Voleti and Wait, 2014). MWCNTs filled with distinct ferromagnetic alloys altered the growth and development of O. sativa seedlings by changing the plant hormones concentration and the C:N ratio (Hao et al., 2016). At low concentrations, the MWCNTs had a positive growth effect on broccoli (Brassica oleracea var. italica) plants (MartínezBallesta et al., 2016). This could open up new perspectives for agriculture and horticulture crops, especially when plants are grown under stress conditions (Martínez-Ballesta et al., 2016). In their study on the effects of MWCNTs on the uptake of pyrene by cucumber (Cucumis sativus L.) plants, X. Shen et al. (2018) reported that the root-to-shoot pyrene movement was increased owing to the co-exposure to
MWCNTs. This was attributed to be an outcome that the analyte circulation in plants could be changed in the presence of MWCNTs (X. Shen et al., 2018). Reports by other researchers revealed that 50 mg L−1 MWCNT could have positive (lateral root number, photosynthesis) as well as phytotoxic (root growth) effects on A. thaliana plants (Fan et al., 2018). The existence of MWCNTs in multiple plant organs of all the exposed crops studied by Lahiani et al. (2017) brought out the importance of risk evaluation in nano-contaminated plants that enter into the food chain.
Findings revealed thatMWCNTs played negative role on seed germination of C. pepo L. and retarded the growth of seedlings under water stress (~1.5 MPa) and in well-water (0 MPa) (Hatami et al., 2017). In collard greens (Brassica oleracea), Deng et al. (2017) found that in a hydroponic environment, the plant biomass productionwas dependent on the concentration of carbamazepine, while exposure of B. oleracea to carboxyl-functionalized-CNTs (concentration 50mg L−1) had increased the plant growth substantially (Deng et al., 2017). In order to study the effects of MWCNTs' uptake in lettuce (Lactuca sativa), Das et al. (2018) had used both pristine (p)-MWCNT and carboxyl-functionalized (c)MWCNT (concentration 20 mg L−1). The authors had developed and used a digestion-Raman analysis approach to detect the presence of the MWCNTs. Both the MWCNT types were found to be present in the leaf, stem and root tissues of the treated L. sativa plants confirming their uptake and translocation in the plant (Das et al., 2018). In order to promote the seedlings growth ofO. sativa, Zhang et al. (2017) had hypothesized a possible link between plant hormones and ROS, under the CNTs treatment. Exposure to SWCNTs and MWCNTs showed deleterious effect in A. thaliana resulting in chromatin condensation, cell aggregation, decrease in cell dry weight, H2O2 accumulation, cell viability, superoxide dismutase activities and chlorophyll content (Zaytseva and Neumann, 2016). This study proved thatMWCNT induced phytotoxicity was connected with the oxidative stress-related disturbances of themicronutrient homeostasis (Zaytseva et al., 2017).
Majority of the above studies found enhancement in seed germination, accelerated vegetative growth and improvement of the yield of fruit/seed using lower concentrations of the CNTs. However, higher amounts of theCNTs caused a decrease in these parameters, underlining the importance of a correct dosage to be used in these experiments.

sections.heading: 2.1.12. Impacts of dendrimers on plants
sections.text:
The dendrimers are highly branched nanosized sphericalmacromolecules with unique molecular properties which make them promising nanocarriers for gene delivery into the cells (Amani et al., 2018). Dendrimers can affect normal seed germination and exert phytotoxic effects on plant systems. Recent studies by Amani et al. (2018) showed that sonication of M. sativa cells with the complex [ssDNA-fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC)-hyperbranched polyamidoamine (hPAMAM)] dendrimer increased the ssDNA delivery efficiency, compared to that of without sonication. It is also well-known that the spherical NPs have higher transfection efficiency than other shapes of the NPs (Jiang et al., 2013).
The spherically shaped dendrimers are mostly regarded as potential nanocargo carriers for gene delivery in plants. As the use of dendrimers is less explored, its dose-dependent beneficial or phytotoxic effects could not be ascertained.

sections.heading: 3. Concluding remarks and future prospects
sections.text:
The present article is an attempt to summarize the impacts of the CNMs in various plant systems. Most of the CNMs are anticipated to be up-taken by the plants and translocated into various parts of the plant body. A part of the absorbed CNMs might promote physiological changes in the plants.
Recent research reports on the applications of permitted doses of the CNMs in a number of crops have shown enhanced germination and seedling growth, accelerated physiological activities (including
photosynthetic activity and nitrogen metabolism), altered miRNA expressions and protein levels accompanied with positive changes in gene expression. These dividends advocate the use of the CNMs in appropriate doses for the purpose of crop improvement.
Various CNMs including the SWCNTs, DWMNTs, MWCNTs, fullerenes and its hydroxyl derivatives (fullerols) have received a lot of attention from the plant biotechnologists on their potential applications in regulating the plant growth. Positive effects of the MWCNTs on legume plant may provide an opportunity to solve the problems of ineffective invasion of rhizobia and low nitrogenase activity (caused by the lack of microelements). Overcoming these difficulties may increase the yield of legume production.
Similarly, carbon dots (CDs) could serve as a kindof fertilizers in horticulture or agriculture and would open newer applications in nanobiotechnology. The CDs are also excellent means of visualization of plant tissues which help in extracting important information on phyototoxicity. This knowledge is of great significance before one recommends the use of a particular CNM for agricultural applications. More importantly, exogenous applications of fullerol have been beneficial in improving the drought tolerance in several plants.
The up-regulation of expression of thewater channel's gene and cell wall formation gene provided confirmation that the CNTs are capable to affect plant physiology through up-regulation genes, important for plant growth and development. Finding a plausible mechanism of how the CNTs activate the expression of certain genes in the plant is still an open question and requires further experimentation.
Currently, a proper understanding of themolecular levelmechanism which would explain the adverse and beneficial effects of the CNMs in plants is lacking. Thus, it cannot be ascertainedwhich specific properties of the CNMs can connect with the expression of genes and proteins that are necessary for the growth of the plant. Upcoming researches need also to be focussed towards obtaining an improved understanding on the CNMs-induced toxicity to plants, translocation of the CNMs inside the plant body and the role of physico-chemical traits of the CNMs in the root system.
As the data on the effects of CNMs in plants are varied and dependent on CNMs type, its physical characteristics, type of plant, dose/concentration of the CNM, method of application, duration of the exposure etc., it is difficult to arrive at a general conclusion. With respect to seed germination, plant health and plant physiology – all these are strongly dose-dependent on CNM type, media, application method, duration and dosage. The CNMs do have a future in agricultural nanotechnology. The agricultural scientists and the field supervisors have the joint responsibility to identify (and implement) the correct dose, application method and duration of application in order to reap the benefits of the use of CNMs. Any laxity in application and field-supervision will bring in a disaster-like situation affecting human health, cattle health and an irreversible damage to the environment. For an effective food safety assessment, confirmatory identification of the toxic CNMs in crop plants becomes a mandatory requirement, which should never be compromised.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2019.02.409.
Conflict of interest
The authors jointly declare that there are no conflicts of interests.
